awd_titl_txt: Crystal orientation and defect control in active and passive plasmonic systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: Noble metals are important materials in electronic and optical systems because they can conduct electrical currents with exceptional ease.  Material defects strongly dictate the electronic, optical, thermal, and structural properties of these metals.  To date, the precise role of defects in device performance is not well understood, in part because there do not exist robust and scalable ways to define defects in metallic structures.  This research project aims to investigate the role of individual defects in the electronic and optical properties of gold devices.  This work leverages a new technique for metal growth that specifies single defects in a simple and scalable way.  An experimental understanding of how to control and characterize defects in noble metals provides new insights into how noble metal devices can be made to be more energy efficient, optically responsive, and mechanically robust.  Experimental quantification of defect properties also enables theoretical researchers to more accurately model devices.  The education component of this project targets engineering education at the high school level, by working with teachers in the lab to provide them with a research perspective in nanotechnology education, and by engaging with high school students through seminars and discussion.

Technical description: In this research project, the principle investigator explores methods to control the crystal orientation, grain boundary orientation, and grain boundary position in single- and bi-crystal gold metal microstructures.  These material systems serve as model systems to explore the role of defects in active and passive plasmonic devices.  A crystal growth technique called rapid melt growth specifies crystal orientation and defects in the metal.  In this technique, a silica microcrucible encapsulates polycrystalline gold and a platinum seed, where the gold is first heated to its melting point and is then cooled.  Liquid phase epitaxy initiates from the seed region, is directional, and specifies the crystal orientations of the metal microstructures based on the seed crystal.  As such, this method serves as a versatile and scalable platform for defining the crystallographic properties of metals through lithographic patterning.  For example, two seed structures at each end of a gold stripe produce bi-crystals with a range of tilt-boundary angles.  The principle investigator aims to correlate parameters, such as tilt-boundary angle, with plasmon transport, using optical and electronic microscopy techniques.  The education component of this project focuses on high school engineering education, by providing teachers with nanotechnology experience and students with summer laboratory programs and seminars.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Metals are essential materials used in all aspects of society, from structural materials for buildings and vehicles and conductors for electronics to catalysts for chemical production.  They are crystalline, meaning they comprise regular arrays of metal atoms, and their intrinsic electronic, optical, and mechanical properties are governed in part by grain boundaries, which are crystal defects within the bulk metal. Depending on the density and type of grain boundaries present, the same metallic materials can exhibit profoundly distinct characteristics. For example, the presence of grain boundaries greatly influences mechanical yield strength, metal corrosion rates, and electrical conductivity. Important metal-catalyzed chemical reactions, such as the reduction of carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide, are enhanced by grain boundary density and energetics.  The optical properties of metals are also strongly tied to the presence of grain boundaries.

A fundamental understanding of the properties of individual grain boundaries is important to elucidate how the physical properties of bulk materials result from the collective response of individual grains and their boundaries, but this understanding remains unresolved.  The focus of this grant has been to develop new methods to create and analyze single metal grain boundaries.  Single grain boundaries are relatively simple and well-defined, making them ideal systems for experimentalists and theorists to accurately corroborate experimental findings with analytic and numerical models.  The effect of single grain boundaries becomes particularly significant for metal structures scaling to the micro- and nanoscale, where many bulk material trends break down.

In this effort, we introduced a new method for experimentally preparing microscale gold bicrystals, which are metal structure that contain individual grain boundaries. With our technique, we achieve a high-throughput, high-yield crystal growth process that can produce many thousands of bicrystals on a single chip, thereby enabling exhaustive structure-property investigations within this important grain boundary parameter space in a comprehensive manner.  Our key findings are as follows.  First, we uncovered the mechanism for bicrystal formation and deduced how the concept can generally extend to a variety of metal systems.  Second, we probed the energetic properties of grain boundaries as a function of grain boundary orientation and found good agreement with established theories, confirming the high quality of our bicrystal system.  Third, we evaluated the mechanical properties of individual grain boundaries by mechanically testing bicrystals in an electron microscope, which allowed us to track the deformation of the grain boundary with single atom precision. This is important to understanding where strength from bulk metal materials comes from.  Fourth, we probed the influence of heat on the electrical properties of individual grain boundaries.  This is important to understanding how metals can be used to measure temperature.  The bicrystal growth method developed in this project will serve as a model system for the systematic engineering of defects in future scientific studies of metal materials.
